awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Design Automation for Microfluidic Large Scale Integration Laboratories-on-a-Chip
awd_abstract_narration:
Emerging laboratory-on-a-chip technology enables automation and miniaturization of biochemical reactions for applications such as DNA sequencing, drug discovery, detection of influenza and other pathogens, biothreat detection, and water purification. Scientists presently must design new devices for each application by hand. This may take weeks or months for complex applications. This project will design and implement computer software that automatically converts a scientist's biological application into a physical device layout that can be fabricated. Successful completion of this project will enhance scientific productivity and lower the barrier-to-entry for new users.
 
In terms of broader impact, laboratories-on-a-chip are expected to improve and reduce the cost of global healthcare, particularly through point-of-care testing. This project will reduce the design cost for laboratories-on-a-chip through productivity enhancements, and these savings can be passed directly to the consumer. At the University of California, Riverside, the PI will introduce undergraduate and graduate courses on laboratory-on-a-chip technology, which will be assessed by a qualified professional development officer. The PI will include women and underrepresented minority students in this project, and has a planned an outreach program with a collaborator at Crafton Hills College to promote computer science education to underrepresented minority high school students in the economically-disadvantaged Inland Empire region of Southern California.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated novel computer-aided design algorithms and software to improve the productivity of designs of microfluidic Large-Scale Integration (mLSI) chips, which have revolutionized biochemistry and bioengineering through automation, miniaturization, and programmability. Prior to this research effort, mLSI chips were designed and physically laid out by hand, which was both time-consuming and tedious; using the semiconductor industry as a metaphor, that design paradigm was stuck in the early 1970s, before the Conway-Mead revolution let to integrated semiconductor VLSI technology and computer-aided design tools, which are now industry standard. The software and algorithms developed in the course of this project provide a viable pathway for software-based design, verification, and evaluation of mLSI chips that was not possible previously.

 

The intellectual merit of this project involved the adaption of algorithms and techniques from semiconductor design to the design of mLSI chips. The project yielded one of the first toolflows for mLSI chip design starting from a high-level specification, yielding to a dramatic reduction in the time, cost, and complexity of mLSI chip design compared to prior practice. These efforts point toward increased scientific access for mLSI technology for biologists and biochemists who will be able to execute assays (biological protocols) of greater complexity than is currently possible in their laboratories today; this will allow them to rapidly advance their respective scientific fields. Reducing the time and cost of mLSI design and fabrication will increase scientific opportunities to apply them to new problems, and commercial opportunities to integrate them into new products and services that can positively transform society, e.g., by lowering the cost of diagnostics and healthcare.

 

The Broader Impacts of this project are numerous. mLSI design automation benefits society by catalyzing scientific advances in fields such as (bio)chemistry, biology, and biotechnology, to positive impact public health and safety; the project addressed a then-unmet need for design productivity tools, as chemists and biologists who are not device experts lack the resources and expertise to design and fabricate their own chips. The project provided support for 11 UCR PhD students, 1 UCR Master’s Student, and more than 50 UCR undergraduates, including 10 women and 14 African American and Latino students, including four peer-reviewed papers co-authored by participating undergraduates. Several project participants took the initiate to train middle and high school teachers in basic programming concepts during the course of the project, including the development of novel curriculum that embedded computational thinking practices into current grade 6-12 curriculum to ensure exposure during high school; participating school districts included Riverside Unified and Elk Grove. The PI also engaged in outreach efforts targeting community college students at Crafton Hills College in Yucaipa, CA. 

 

The project also featured an extensive effort to integrate the PI’s research program with his educational efforts at UC Riverside. The PI supervised the teaching of two student-facilitated R’Courses at UC Riverside, which focused on microfluidic technologies, taught in the Computer Science and Bioengineering Departments, respectively. The PI also taught an interdisciplinary course for UCR engineering undergraduates with a lecturer in the Department of Bioengineering. The course covered topics such as laboratory automation, microfluidics, robotic liquid handling, scheduling laboratory experiments, and web interfaces; 24 students in total took this course. The PI has also integrated research insights gleaned from this project into the undergraduate and graduate courses that he regularly teaches, and supervises undergraduates who enroll in independent study units on topics relevant to this award and its research activities.
